No Poverty.reason: The course covers historical "economic trends" and "colonial society," which may tangentially relate to the economic conditions and poverty of the era, but it is not a focus.

Quality Education.reason: The course is an educational offering and explicitly aims to help students "develop their English-language reading, speaking, and writing skills."

Decent Work and Economic Growth.reason: The course explicitly covers "slavery," a form of forced labor, and analyzes historical "economic trends," which are central to this SDG.

Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure.reason: The topics of "westward expansion" and "economic trends" in the period up to 1877 infer early industrialization and infrastructure development, though not explicitly detailed.

Reduced Inequalities.reason: The course explicitly focuses on topics central to historical inequality, including the study of "Native Americans" and "slavery."

Sustainable Cities and Communities.reason: The study of "colonial society" and "westward expansion" relates to the formation of settlements and communities, but lacks any mention of sustainability.

Life on Land.reason: The course covers "exploration of the New World" and "westward expansion," which inherently involve land use, settlement, and interaction with terrestrial ecosystems.

Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions.reason: The course is fundamentally about the formation of a nation's institutions, covering the "Revolutionary War," "Constitution," "Mexican War," "political parties," and "Civil War/Reconstruction."
evidence: the development of the political parties, and the Civil War/Reconstruction
